bio.title: Author biography
bio.p: Nisha Mukherjee is a PhD Candidate in the Department of Political Science at the University of Missouri. Her dissertation, entitled ‘The Political Economy of Human Well-Being’, assesses the political determinants of human well-being.

author-notes.corresp: Nisha Mukherjee, 113 Professional Building, Department of Political Science, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO 65211-6030, USA. Email: nm3v7@mail.mizzou.edu

abstract.p: This article analyses the impact of party systems on human well-being and argues that multiparty systems are associated with better welfare outcomes for two primary reasons: first, multiparty systems provide representation to multiple issue-dimensions in society, thereby indicating a more inclusive system, which ensures that diverse societal interests are taken into account during formulation of welfare policies. Second, multiparty systems also indicate a competitive party system, which provides incentives for parties to perform effectively while in office and propels parties to appeal to multiple segments of society by providing broader welfare services. The impact of party systems on human well-being is tested on a global sample of 68 democratic countries from 1975–2000. The findings show support for the hypothesized relationship between party systems and human well-being.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Political institutions play an important role in society by providing structure and organization to politics. They constrain and mould behaviour of political agents by providing the contours within which political agents interact with each other and society, thereby influencing the way politics unfolds within a state. The significance of political institutions has been emphasized by prominent scholars such as Lijphart (1999) and Norris (2004), who have drawn attention to the importance of institutional engineering in improving democratic governance. One such political institution is the nature of party systems.

Political parties serve multiple functions in a polity. They structure political competition in a society, formulate public policies, serve as critics of government and act as intermediaries between the citizens and the government, thereby serving as important conveyors of societal interests, to name a few (Merriam, 1923; Norris, 2004). The variety of functions performed by political parties is indicative of the important role of parties in a political system.

Emphasizing the role of political parties, the existing literature analyses the impact of partisanship on policy outcomes (Alesina and Roubini, 1997; Blais et al., 1993; Castles, 1989; Hibbs, 1977, 1992; Lange and Garrett, 1985; Schmidt, 1996). This article focuses on a different dimension of political parties by assessing the impact of party systems on human well-being, as proxied by infant mortality, child mortality and life expectancy. 1

I argue that multiparty systems, measured by the effective number of parliamentary parties, enhance welfare outcomes for two primary reasons: first, multiparty systems provide representation to multiple issue-dimensions in society, thereby indicating a more representative or inclusive system, which ensures that diverse societal interests are taken into account during formulation of welfare policies. Second, multiparty systems indicate a competitive party system, which provides incentives for parties to perform effectively while in office and propels parties to appeal to multiple segments of society by providing broader welfare services.

The article is organized as follows. Section I provides an overview of the literature on the determinants of human welfare and discusses the existing research on political parties and its consequences. Section II lays out the theoretical mechanisms through which multiparty systems enhance human well-being. Section III tests the hypothesized relationship between multiparty systems and human well-being. Section IV discusses the findings of the quantitative analyses followed by sensitivity analyses to test the robustness of the findings. Section V provides concluding remarks and policy implications of this article.

sec.title: I. The determinants of human well-being
sec.p: The existing literature focuses on three alternative determinants of human well-being. One body of literature argues that democracies lead to greater welfare for the poor. A number of studies show that democracies have lower infant and child mortality rates and thus lead to better welfare outcomes (Boone, 1996; Dasgupta, 1993; Lake and Baum, 2001; Moon and Dixon, 1985; Przeworski et al., 2000). The reasoning behind this theory is that democracies spend more on public goods and services because of the electoral process, which makes democracies more competitive and participatory in nature (Shin, 1989), more accountable to the needs of citizens (Deacon, 2003) and constrains democratic leaders from extracting rents from society (Lake and Baum, 2001). Autocracies, on the other hand, do not face such electoral constraints. Thus, democracies are more beneficial for the poor.

However, Ross (2006) criticizes this literature by arguing that most of these studies are characterized by selection bias and methodological shortcomings, and that once these are accounted for there are no significant differences between regime type and human welfare. He concludes by suggesting that there is need to go beyond exploring the impact of regimes and analysing other political determinants of human well-being.

Moreover, analysing the impact of regime-type on welfare outcomes may also be tantamount to overlooking the large variation within regimes. Democracies, for instance, may differ from one another on account of their political institutions, like executive systems, party systems, electoral systems, unitary versus federal systems, bicameral versus unicameral systems, among others. These different institutional arrangements may provide greater leverage in explaining the variation in welfare outcomes among democracies as against aggregate measures of regime type. This article makes an attempt to do so by analysing the impact of party systems on human well-being.

The other strand of literature that provides an alternative explanation of welfare outcomes focuses on social spending. Existing studies show that higher levels of social spending lead to better welfare outcomes (Baldacci et al., 2004; Gomanee et al., 2005; Gupta et al., 1999). This line of reasoning also makes intuitive sense because we would expect higher social expenditure to lead to higher levels of human well-being.

More recently, scholars have been exploring institutional determinants of human welfare where parliamentary systems (Gerring et al., 2009) and centripetal systems (Gerring et al., 2005) are found to enhance welfare outcomes. 2 In evaluating the impact of party systems on human well-being, the article contributes to this emerging literature analysing the consequences of political institutions. More specifically, since centripetalism is also characterized by multiparty systems (Gerring et al., 2005), this article builds on the concept of centripetalism by theorizing and assessing the impact of one of the features of centripetal systems on welfare outcomes.

sec.title: Political parties and consequences
sec.p: The literature on the consequences of political parties has been largely restricted to the impact of partisanship on policy outcomes. The conventional wisdom on partisanship indicates that left-leaning governments are more likely to have higher levels of social spending (Alesina and Roubini, 1997; Blais et al., 1993; Castles, 1989; Hibbs, 1977, 1992; Lange and Garrett, 1985; Schmidt, 1996), higher redistributive outcomes (Bradley et al., 2003; Iverson and Soskice, 2006), or lower levels of inequality (Huber et al., 2006). However, some of the more recent literature argues that left-leaning governments do not always pursue policies that are consistent with the conventional wisdom (Huber et al., 2008; Johnson and Crisp, 2003; Stokes, 2001; Tavits and Letki, 2009), thereby indicating that party policies may change subject to the incentives and opportunities that political parties are confronted with.

Thus, the above-discussed literature indicates a lack of consensus among scholars about the link between party identity and policy outcomes. This article adopts a different approach by analysing the impact of party systems because the environment in which parties operate may also have an impact on the nature of policies adopted (D’Alimonte, 1999; Enelow and Hinich, 1990; Strom and Muller, 1999). Contemporary research emphasizes the significance of party systems by analysing its impact on the size of government (Mukherjee, 2003), public expenditure (Chhibber and Nooruddin, 2004; Crepaz and Moser, 2004) and conflict (Wilkinson, 2004). However, the impact of party systems on human well-being in a cross-national setting has not been addressed so far and this article seeks to fill the existing lacuna in the literature.

sec.title: II. Effective number of parliamentary parties and human well-being
sec.p: I argue that multiparty systems measured by the effective number of parliamentary parties (ENPP from now on) 3 may enhance welfare outcomes because they are indicative of a more inclusive society and a competitive party system. I elaborate upon both these theoretical explanations below.

Institutional models like consensual and centripetal systems emphasize inclusiveness in a political system as being beneficial for political outcomes. Lijphart’s (1999) consensual model comprises institutions that promote representation and participation by giving voice to diverse interests in society such that consensual systems not only enhance the quality of democracy but also produce favourable welfare outcomes. 4 Similarly, Gerring et al.’s (2005) centripetal model comprises institutions that emphasize the significance of representation and inclusion of diverse ideas, interests and identities into the political system. 5 Both these institutional models consist of multiparty systems, thereby emphasizing the nature of party systems in a polity. Multiparty systems are indicative of a more inclusive system because they provide an opportunity for multiple issue-dimensions in society to find representation in the political system (Lijphart, 1999).

One of the ways that human welfare can be improved is by formulating policies that cater to the needs of the population (WHO, 1997) and ensuring its effective implementation (World Bank, 2003, 2004). Parties have intimate knowledge of the specific welfare needs of their supporters and they are better able to influence welfare policies if they find representation in legislatures. Multiparty systems are characterized by participation, deliberation, consensus and compromise among groups representing diverse interests, which leads to the formulation of comprehensive policies that incorporate the welfare needs of multiple segments of society, thereby resulting in welfare-enhancing outcomes for the society as a whole.

The case of Kerela, in India, helps illustrate this point. Human welfare in the state of Kerela is higher than the average level of human welfare in the rest of the country (Kenny, 2005; Véron, 2001). One of the reasons for the success of welfare outcomes in Kerela can be attributed to the government that has provided broad-based services to the people (World Bank, 2004). The state of Kerela has been a multiparty system with a high effective number of political parties since the 1960s. 6 Chiriyankandath (1997), while analysing the nature of coalition governments in Kerela, illustrates how the inclusion of the Muslim League political party in governmental coalitions between 1960 and 1979 led to a greater diversion of resources towards education since the Muslims were lagging behind in education as compared to the other communities in the state. Not only did this benefit the Muslim community specifically, it led to a considerable increase in overall levels of literacy in the state. Thus, a multiparty system in Kerela provided an opportunity for the Muslim League to bring attention to the welfare needs of their supporters, and participate in the formulation of policies that subsequently benefited the relatively deprived segments of society and enhanced overall levels of well-being as well.

Multiparty systems may also be associated with better welfare outcomes because they are indicative of a more competitive party system, since parties face high levels of competition in order to find representation in legislatures. A competitive party system presents citizens with alternative options that can potentially replace a non-performing incumbent party. This presents additional electoral incentives for political parties to perform effectively while in office and makes them more accountable such that they cater to the welfare needs of the citizens.

Additionally, a competitive party system also motivates parties to seek support of multiple groups in society for greater electoral gains. Wilkinson (2004) uses this logic to draw the link between high ENEP (effective number of electoral parties) and reduced violence among the Indian states. He argues that states with high ENEP in India present incentives for parties to provide security to minorities and prevent violence, especially if these minorities comprise swing voters whose support may be crucial to finding representation in legislatures. Thus, the competitive nature of party systems induces parties to appeal to multiple segments of society in order to maximize their opportunity for representation. 7 Political parties can make appeals to multiple groups by adopting policies and providing welfare services to groups outside their support base, thereby enhancing the overall level of human welfare.

The extent to which parties make broader appeals to multiple segments of society for electoral purposes can be illustrated through the example of party behaviour in Thailand. The average number of effective parties in Thailand is five, indicating a competitive party system. 8 The Thai Rak Thai party has been associated with populist policies in Thailand since 2001, when the party came to power and formed a coalition government (McCargo, 2002). Though most of the improvement in human welfare in Thailand has been attributed to the policies adopted by the Thai Rak Thai-led coalition government, e.g. a micro-credit development fund for villages, a subsidized universal healthcare and low-cost universal access to anti-retroviral HIV medication, among others (HDR 2007), subsequent efforts have been made by other parties to provide welfare services to the poor. For instance, in the 2007 elections, the Democrat Party in Thailand, whose support base primarily comprised the relatively richer segments of society, adopted a populist platform to woo the rural areas (Schafferer, 2008). The Democrat Party’s emphasis on populist policies indicates that even though their support base consisted of the middle and upper strata of society, they had to appeal to the masses with the promise of providing them with welfare benefits due to high levels of party competition. Thus, a competitive party system in Thailand led the Democrat Party to compromise on its ideology and appeal to the poor in order to win elections. 9

Apart from the two primary explanations identified above that link multiparty systems to human well-being, a high ENPP can enhance welfare outcomes via an indirect mechanism as well. Existing studies indicate that multiparty systems are associated with greater levels of overall spending because fragmented legislatures necessitate the need for parties to compromise with one another in order to implement policies and ensure the smooth functioning of legislatures (Blais et al., 1993; Grilli et al., 1991; Perotti and Kontopoulos, 2002; Persson and Tabellini, 1999; Roubini and Sachs, 1989). Since a large number of parties need to be accommodated in this process, it results in higher levels of spending in order to satisfy the multiple parties involved in negotiations. If multiparty systems are associated with higher levels of social spending, 10 then it is reasonable to expect the beneficial effects of higher social spending on human welfare; especially, since the existing literature shows the positive impact of social or health spending on welfare outcomes (Baldacci et al., 2004; Gomanee et al., 2005; Gupta et al., 1999). Thus, multiparty systems may enhance human well-being via social spending as well. 11
Having laid out the theoretical argument linking party systems to human well-being, I now turn to my primary hypothesis:
Hypothesis 1: Countries with a higher effective number of parliamentary parties are associated with higher levels of human well-being.

sec.title: III. Data and methods
sec.p:
The impact of party systems on human well-being is analysed on a sample of 68 democratic countries over the time period 1975 to 2000. I measure human well-being with three variables: infant mortality, child mortality and life expectancy. These are some of the most commonly used indicators of human well-being in the existing literature (Baldacci et al., 2004; Boone, 1996; Dasgupta, 1993; Gupta et al., 1999; Lake and Baum, 2001; McGuire, 2006; Moon and Dixon, 1985; Przeworski et al., 2000; Ross, 2006). 12
Infant mortality refers to the number of deaths of infants (of one year or less) per 1000 live births. Child mortality refers to the number of deaths per 1000 inhabitants of children under 5 years of age. Life expectancy refers to the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of his/her birth were to remain the same for the rest of his/her life. I use log values of these variables to normalize their distribution, given that each is skewed. The data for the dependent variables come from World Development Indicators (World Bank, 2007). Lower levels of infant and child mortality and higher levels of life expectancy indicate better welfare outcomes. The primary independent variable is the effective number of parliamentary parties (ENPP) and the data come from Golder (2005). 13

To ward against omitted variable bias, I control for some prominent alternative explanations of human well-being. As noted earlier, a number of scholars have argued that democracies are more likely to have higher levels of human well-being because the government is responsible to the people (Boone, 1996; Dasgupta, 1993; Lake and Baum, 2001; Moon and Dixon, 1985; Przeworski et al., 2000). I use the polity2 variable to measure level of democracy from the Polity IV data (Marshall and Jaggers, 2007). The measure ranges from a scale of −10 to +10, where positive values indicate a higher level of democracy. Since this article analyses the impact of ENPP on welfare outcomes among democracies, only countries with polity2 > 0 have been included in the analyses. Thus, the data for the level of democracy in this article range from 1 to 10. 14 The level of economic development may also influence human well-being. High levels of economic development provide greater private and public resources for food and health, thereby enhancing welfare outcomes. I measure economic development with logged per capita GDP. The data for per capita GDP come from World Development Indicators (World Bank, 2007).

Another common control variable is the total population of a country (Enikolopov and Zhuravskaya, 2007; Gerring et al., 2009; Lake and Baum, 2001; Zweifel and Navia, 2000). The logic is that governments may have difficulty effectively distributing human services throughout large populations. I use the logged value of population size and the data come from World Development Indicators (World Bank, 2007). The presence of inequality in the country may also have an impact on human well-being. A high level of inequality is indicative of an unequal society. Insofar as some individuals lack resources to attain basic healthcare services, inequality is likely to affect human well-being adversely. The data for inequality come from Solt (2009).

The prevailing literature argues that states which are ethnically diverse are likely to provide fewer public goods due to lack of consensus among different ethnic groups about the kind of public goods to be provided (Alesina et al., 1999; Easterly and Levine, 1997). Thus, one may expect ethnically diverse states to have lower levels of human well-being. Ethnic heterogeneity is measured as a probability, which ranges from 0 to 1 where higher values indicate greater ethnic diversity and the data come from Alesina et al. (2003).

Countries closer to the equator may be expected to have lower levels of human well-being because they may be more vulnerable to disease (Sachs and Warner, 1997) Thus, all models include a climate variable, which measures the proportion of the country that lies between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn and ranges from 0 to 1. The data for this variable come from Bleaney and Nishiyama (2002). Countries with an English legal origin (or prior British colonies) or having been under socialist rule in the past may produce better welfare outcomes as indicated by prior research (Gerring et al., 2005, 2009). Thus all models include dummies for these two variables and the data for both come from LaPorta et al. (1999).

Ideologically polarized legislatures may make it difficult for parties to reach consensus on policies to enhance welfare outcomes. I control for ideological polarization in legislatures, which is a measure of polarization between the executive party, the three largest government parties and the largest opposition party. 15 The variable ranges from 0 to 2, where higher values indicate higher levels of polarization and the data come from the Database of Political Institutions (Keefer and Stasavage, 2003). A parliamentary systems dummy is included to capture institutional differences between countries that may influence human well-being (Gerring et al., 2009) and the data for parliamentary systems come from Golder (2005).

I also include regional dummies for Africa, Latin America and Asia to control for distinct cultural, geographic and historical factors common to these regions. Developed countries are technologically and economically more advanced and may have higher levels of human welfare as compared to developing countries. In order to capture this difference, an OECD dummy is included in all models, where a value of 1 indicates membership of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and 0 otherwise. I use the World Bank classification of the OECD countries.

I utilize time-series cross-sectional (TSCS) analyses to examine variations across countries and over time. 16 Unit root tests indicate that the three dependent variables are non-stationary. 17 This indicates that the dependent variables are trended over time. I include a time trend variable in all the models to control for the trended dependent variables. 18 The data indicate some serial correlation so the models have been estimated with a prais-winsten correction for first-order autocorrelation. 19 Since the primary independent variable, ENPP does not vary much over time, I do not use a fixed effects estimation technique (Beck, 2001; Beck and Katz, 2001). However, as discussed above, I do include regional dummies to address the problem of regional heterogeneity to an extent. The independent variables have been lagged by one year to reduce the possibility of reverse causality. In order to deal with problems of heteroskedasticity, all models have been estimated by clustering on countries. 20

sec.title: Findings
sec.p: Table 1 shows the impact of ENPP on human well-being. Models 1–3 analyse the impact of ENPP on infant mortality, child mortality and life expectancy, respectively. ENPP is statistically significant in all three models and in the expected direction. The results indicate that a higher number of parliamentary parties are associated with better welfare outcomes. A high ENPP reduces infant and child mortality and increases life expectancy, thereby providing support for the hypotheses postulated in the article. In substantive terms, as ENPP increases from its minimum to its maximum value, it reduces infant mortality by 11 percent, reduces child mortality by 24 percent and increases life expectancy by 0.5 percent. 21 The substantive impact seems to be greater in the case of infant and child mortality, while it is much more modest in the case of life expectancy.

caption.p: Impact of ENPP on human well-being.

fn.p: Standard errors in parentheses: *p<0.1, **p<0.05, ***p<0.01.

sec.p: In terms of control variables, the level of democracy is significant in the first two models. Higher levels of democracy are associated with lower levels of infant and child mortality. This is consistent with the prevailing literature that more democratic countries produce better welfare outcomes. Higher levels of GDP per capita are associated with lower levels of infant and child mortality and higher levels of life expectancy. The impact of GDP per capita provides support to the argument that a higher level of GDP per capita produces better welfare outcomes because it increases the availability of resources for investments in health.

Total size of the population is also statistically significant. Larger populations are associated with higher infant and child mortality and lower levels of life expectancy, indicating that states with a larger population produce worse health outcomes. The inequality coefficient, however, fails to reach statistical levels of significance in all three models, though the signs of the coefficients are in the expected direction. Ethnic heterogeneity is positively associated with infant and child mortality but negatively associated with life expectancy, indicating that ethnically diverse societies adversely influence welfare outcomes.

Climate, parliamentary systems and polarized legislature variables do not reach statistical levels of significance. Regarding the impact of regional dummies, African countries have lower levels of life expectancy, while Asian countries have lower levels of infant and child mortality. These findings indicate that specific regional features (cultural, historical or geographic) influence welfare outcomes in countries as well. The OECD dummy is statistically significant in all three models, indicating that the developed countries are associated with lower levels of infant and child mortality and higher levels of life expectancy.

The English legal origin dummy is negative in models 1 and 2, indicating that countries without an English legal origin have higher levels of infant and child mortality. This is consistent with the prevailing argument that countries with an English legal origin are associated with better welfare outcomes. However, model 3 indicates that countries with an English legal origin are associated with lower levels of life expectancy. Even though this is an inconsistent finding with respect to life expectancy, previous studies show similar results (Gerring et al., 2005, 2009). Countries with a socialist past are also associated with lower levels of infant and child mortality. Lastly, the time trend variable is statistically significant in all three models, indicating the trended nature of the dependent variables.

sec.title: Sensitivity analyses
sec.p: Additional tests were conducted to test the robustness of the findings. First, baseline models were also estimated with an alternative indicator of legislative diversity. I use the measure ‘legislative fractionalization’ from the Database of Political Institutions (Beck et al., 2001), which is a measure of probability that two legislators picked at random from the legislature will belong to two different parties and the data range from 0 to 1, where higher values indicate greater diversity. Table 2 , shows the findings and the results indicate that the main theoretical variable of interest, legislative fractionalization, remains statistically significant in all three models, which provides greater support to the positive impact of legislative diversity on human well-being.

caption.p: Impact of legislative fractionalization on human well-being.

fn.p: Standard errors in parentheses: *p<0.1, **p<0.05, ***p<0.01.

sec.p: Second, the article argues that apart from the two primary mechanisms, ENPP also enhances human well-being indirectly through social spending. I test this indirect mechanism in two stages. The first stage analyses the impact of ENPP on various spending outcomes and the second stage includes ENPP and health spending in the baseline models and analyses the impact of both these variables on human well-being. I use three different spending variables from the OECD database (2010): total government spending as a percentage of GDP, social spending as a percentage of GDP and health spending as a percentage of GDP. 22 Drawing on model specifications used by Persson and Tabellini (2002, 2004), I control for the level of democracy, income, total population, parliamentary systems, climate, ethnic heterogeneity and region dummies. 23 Additionally, I control for the log of district magnitude, rate of inflation, total trade and age-dependency ratio. Data for district magnitude come from Johnson and Wallack (2006) and for all other variables from the WDI (World Bank, 2007).

Beginning with the first stage of analysis, I examine whether high ENPP increases total social spending, health spending and total government spending. Table 3 , shows the findings and the results indicate that ENPP has a statistically significant and positive impact on the three different kinds of spending outcome, which provides support for the first step of the indirect mechanism.

caption.p: Impact of ENPP on spending outcomes.

fn.p: Standard errors in parentheses: *p<0.1, **p<0.05, ***p<0.01.
No data on total government spending for Latin American countries (Model 3).

sec.p:
In the second stage of the indirect mechanism, I include both ENPP and health spending in the baseline models. 24
Table 4 , presents the results. We see that both ENPP and health spending are significant and in the expected direction in the three models. This indicates that ENPP may have an independent direct impact on welfare outcomes, besides the indirect impact via greater spending. Overall, this provides support for the indirect mechanism by showing the positive impact of ENPP on spending outcomes as well as the positive impact of health spending on human well-being.

caption.p: Impact of ENPP and health spending on human well-being.

fn.p: Standard errors in parentheses: *p<0.1, **p<0.05, ***p<0.01.

sec.p: Third, the baseline models were estimated with additional control variables, e.g. tax revenue (as a percentage of GDP) and log of district magnitude. Table 5 , presents the results. The impact of ENPP still remains statistically significant for infant and child mortality, but becomes insignificant in the case of life expectancy. This indicates that the relationship between ENPP and welfare outcomes is more robust for infant and child mortality as compared to life expectancy. Fourth, the baseline models estimate the impact of ENPP on human well-being for minimally democratic countries (with a democratic score of polity2 > 0). As a sensitivity test, the models were estimated with a higher threshold of democracy (polity2 > 7 and polity2 > 5). The results for infant and child mortality remain robust under both these cut-off points. However, life expectancy does not remain significant when we look at more democratic countries with polity2 > 5. 25 Thus, once again, it seems that the impact of ENPP is more robust in the case of infant and child mortality as compared to life expectancy.

caption.p: Impact of ENPP on human well-being (with additional controls: tax revenue and district magnitude).

fn.p: Standard errors in parentheses: *p<0.1, **p<0.05, ***p<0.01.

sec.p: Fifth, I explored the possibility of an interactive effect between parliamentary systems and ENPP, but the findings did not indicate any significant interactive effect between the two. Lastly, I looked at the possibility of a non-linear relationship between ENPP and welfare outcomes by using various dummy variables as well as a quadratic term. However, the results do not show any indication of a consistent non-linear pattern. Overall, these robustness tests indicate that high ENPP improves human well-being, especially infant and child mortality.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article analyses the impact of party systems on human well-being and shows that multiparty systems are associated with better welfare outcomes. A higher number of ENPP indicates a more representative and competitive system, which enhances human well-being directly and indirectly via greater spending. In making this argument and presenting evidence that supports the theoretical link between effective number of parties and welfare outcomes, this article explains variation in human well-being among democracies. The article disaggregates democratic regimes in terms of party systems and contributes to the existing literature analysing the consequences of other institutions, e.g. parliamentary (Gerring et al., 2009) or centripetal systems (Gerring et al., 2005).

Since human welfare is a core attribute of development in general (Sen, 1999), an understanding of the factors that influence overall development is essential to work towards improving the quality of life people lead. As international organizations like the United Nations and its subsidiaries WHO, WFO and UNDP are working towards the enhancement of human well-being and development more generally, this article offers an institutional alternative to improving welfare outcomes.

The policy implications of the article suggest that a larger number of parties are beneficial for human well-being. While it may be difficult to change the number of parties in a country, one can modify electoral laws that influence party systems (Duverger, 1954; Rae, 1971; Riker, 1982). The findings of this article are especially relevant for newly transitioned countries contemplating institutional alternatives that can maximize the welfare of their citizens. Citizens' support for political leaders is largely determined by whether the leaders are concerned about the welfare of their citizens or not. Adopting institutions that promote multiparty systems may be beneficial for citizens, given the positive impact of multiparty systems on welfare outcomes.

Future research can identify other institutional factors that enhance welfare outcomes; for instance, the relative advantages or disadvantages of unitary versus federal systems can be one avenue of future research. The objective of this article is to explain the variation in welfare outcomes among democracies. Alternatively, future research can also identify the factors that could potentially explain variation in welfare outcomes among autocracies. This line of research has not been explored so far, largely because of the lack of good data among autocracies. However, if the data problems can be overcome, then future research in this direction can be a good contribution to the literature on human well-being.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
The terms ‘human well-being’, ‘human welfare’ and ‘welfare outcomes' are used interchangeably to avoid redundancy.

The term ‘centripetal systems' or ‘centripetalism’ comprises institutions that are inclusive and have centralized authority (Gerring et al., 2005). More specifically, the primary centripetal institutions are unitary, unicameral or weak bicameral, parliamentary and party-list proportional electoral systems. See Gerring et al. (2005) for an overview of other institutional features of centripetal systems.

I use the measure of effective number of parliamentary parties (ENPP) to analyse the impact of party systems. ENPP takes into account each party that wins seats and the share of seats won by each party in an election. ENPP is a more appropriate measure than the effective number of electoral parties (which takes into account each party that wins votes and the share of votes won by each party in an election) or the mere number of political parties in a country because the theoretical argument hinges on the role played by the political parties in legislatures (as discussed in this section). Thus, ENPP is a better measure of party systems for the purpose of this article. Appendix A provides information on the calculation of ENPP.

Lijphart’s (1999) consensual model comprises multiparty coalitions, balance of power between the executive and legislative, multiparty systems, proportional electoral systems, coordinated and corporatist interest groups, federal and decentralized government, bicameral legislature, rigid constitutions, judicial review and independent central banks.

Centripetal systems are similar to consensual systems in that both emphasize an inclusive political system. However, in contrast to consensual systems, centripetal systems emphasize centralized authority, while consensual systems emphasize decentralized authority. More specifically, one key difference between the consensual and the centripetal model is that while the former emphasizes federal systems, centripetal models emphasize unitary systems because they are indicative of centralized power. See Lijphart (1999) and Gerring et al. (2005) for a detailed overview of the consensual and centripetal systems.
Based on Chhibber and Nooruddin’s (2004) calculation of effective number of parties in Kerela, India.

Interestingly, Chhibber and Nooruddin (2004) analyse the impact of ENPP on public goods expenditure in India and argue that two-party systems produce higher levels of public expenditure because, given India’s SMPD system, two-party states provide incentives for parties to appease other social groups by providing higher levels of public goods. In multiparty states, on the other hand, parties provide club goods to specific groups instead of public goods. Using the same logic of electoral incentives, Wilkinson (2004) argues that multiparty states in India provide incentives for parties to provide greater protection to the minorities compared to two-party states. Thus, the findings of the two studies on India reach contradictory findings about the way multiparty versus two-party states behave given the single-member plurality system. The argument made in this article is consistent with the theory postulated by Wilkinson about the impact of multiparty systems.

Even though the Democrat Party lost the 2007 elections, high levels of party competition motivated the party to appeal to various segments of society, as we would expect to observe, given the competitive nature of the party system.

The literature discussed above refers to overall spending levels (which includes expenditures such as overall government spending, social spending, among others). This article is primarily concerned with social spending, since this is relevant to human well-being.

The hypothesized link between ENPP and human well-being discussed here is applicable to both presidential and parliamentary systems because the causal mechanisms focus on negotiation, compromise and interaction between parties primarily in legislatures where both the governing and opposition parties play an important role in influencing welfare outcomes.

Moreover, infant mortality, especially, is a good indicator of human well-being because it captures other important social conditions for which extensive data are not available, such as female education and literary, access to clean water and sanitation, prenatal and neonatal health services and caloric intake (Lipton and Ravallion, 1995; Ross, 2006; Sen, 1999; Victoria et al., 2003).

Appendix A shows how ENPP is calculated. The measure of ENPP used in this article considers ‘independents/others' as a single party (see Appendix A). The models were also estimated with a measure of ENPP, which treats ‘independent/others' differently (for details, see Golder, 2005). However, in both cases, the impact of ENPP remains statistically significant. Appendix B provides summary statistics on ENPP for all countries included in the sample.
All countries that get a polity score greater than 0 for any of the years between 1975 and 2000 are included in the analyses.
See DPI (2009) for a detailed description of the variable.
All analyses were carried out in Stata 10.
The xtfisher stata command is used to test for unit root.
Gerring et al. (2005, 2009) employ a similar technique to address the problem of trended dependent variables.
The xtserial stata command is used to test for serial correlation.
Appendix C provides summary statistics of all the variables.
The substantive impact, however, needs to be interpreted with caution, since I do not use a fixed effects estimation technique because ENPP does not change much over time.

The OECD database has data for a large number of developed and a few developing countries. This restricts the sample size, but unfortunately cross-national spending data for a large number of countries over time are not readily available.
Since these variables are also included in the baseline models, the data sources have already been identified.
Even when I include social spending instead of health spending, both ENPP and social spending remain statistically significant.
